pc.name: Mario
pc.description: Mario serves as the main protagonist of the game. Luigi, Mario's brother, appears only as the second player and plays identically to Mario. While Luigi is differentiated by his colors, both Fiery Mario and Fiery Luigi have the same palette.

image.name: Super Mario's sprite from Super Mario Bros.

pc.name: Luigi
pc.description: Mario serves as the main protagonist of the game. Luigi, Mario's brother, appears only as the second player and plays identically to Mario. While Luigi is differentiated by his colors, both Fiery Mario and Fiery Luigi have the same palette.

image.name: Sprite of Luigi from Super Mario Bros.

npc.name: Princess Toadstool
npc.description: The princess of the Mushroom Kingdom. Bowser kidnaps her to prevent her from reversing the magic the Koopa used on the Mushroom People. She appears in the final course, 8-4 where she thanks Mario[9] for rescusing her and offers a "new quest" for him.

image.name: Princess Peach in Super Mario Bros..

npc.name: Mushroom retainers
npc.description: Seven Mushroom People that are servants of the princess and prisoners of the Koopa. They appear in every castle except for the final one. Mario can rescue a retainer by finishing a castle in World 1 to World 7. They'll say, "Thank you Mario/Luigi! But our princess is in another castle!"

image.name: A Mushroom Retainer from Super Mario Bros.

enemy.name: Little Goomba
enemy.description: Mushroom creatures that walk back and forth. Little Goombas are the most common enemies and can be defeated with any attack.

image.name: Sprite of a Goomba from Super Mario Bros.

enemy.name: Koopa Troopa
enemy.description: Foot soldiers of the Turtle Empire. Stomping on Koopa Troopas make them recede into their shells, which can be kicked to hit defeat enemies. Like Little Goombas, green-shelled Koopa Troopas walk off ledges.

image.name: Sprite of a green Koopa Troopa from Super Mario Bros.

enemy.name: Koopa Paratroopa
enemy.description: Winged Koopa Troopas. The green ones bounce across the ground or fly back and forth in set paths.

image.name: Sprite of a green Koopa Paratroopa from Super Mario Bros.

enemy.name: Buzzy Beetle
enemy.description: Small Koopas that retract into their shells when stomped. Buzzy Beetles are immune to fireballs and replace Little Goombas in Hard Mode.

image.name: A Buzzy Beetle, from Super Mario Bros.

enemy.name: Hammer Brother
enemy.description: Helmeted Koopas that toss hammers. Hammer Brothers periodically hop between rows of blocks. They always occur in pairs.

image.name: Sprite of Hammer Bro from Super Mario Bros.

enemy.name: Spiny
enemy.description: Squat, spiked Koopas. Stomping one damages Mario.

image.name: Sprite of a Spiny from Super Mario Bros.

enemy.name: Spiny's egg
enemy.description: The spiked eggs tossed by Lakitus. They hatch into Spinies when they make contact with the ground.

image.name: Sprite of a Spiny Egg from Super Mario Bros.

enemy.name: Lakitu
enemy.description: Cloud-riding Koopas. Lakitus toss Spiny's eggs. They appear towards the top of the screen follow Mario's position.

image.name: Sprite of Lakitu from Super Mario Bros.

enemy.name: Piranha plant
enemy.description: Carnivorous plants that sit in pipes. Piranha plants emerge and retract from pipes in set internals. If Mario stands directly next to or on these pipes, the plants do not emerge.

image.name: Sprite of a Piranha Plant from Super Mario Bros.

enemy.name: Cheep-cheep
enemy.description: Pudgy pufferfish enemies that swim through water. In some ground-themed courses, red Cheep-cheeps leap over bridges in large numbers.

image.name: Sprite of a red Cheep Cheep from Super Mario Bros.

enemy.name: Bullet Bill
enemy.description: Missiles launched from Turtle Cannons. They fly in straight lines. Bullet Bills are unaffected by fireballs.

image.name: Bullet Bill

enemy.name: Bloober
enemy.description: Underwater squid sentinels. They swim erratically to strike Mario.

image.name: Sprite of a Blooper from Super Mario Bros.

obstacle.name: Fire-Bar
obstacle.description: Various fireballs stacked together moving either clockwise or counterclockwise. Their length may vary.

image.name: Sprite of a Fire Bar from Super Mario Bros.

obstacle.name: Koopa's fire
obstacle.description: Flames spewed by Bowser and his imposters. The fire travels horizontally and transcends walls.

image.name: Sprite of Bowser's Flame from Super Mario Bros.

obstacle.name: Lava
obstacle.description: Pools of molten rock found within fortresses and castles. Direct contact makes Mario lose a life.

image.name: Sprite tile of lava from Super Mario Bros.

obstacle.name: Turtle Cannon
obstacle.description: Cannons that launch Bullet Bills. Like the pipes that contain Piranha plants, Turtle Cannons do not fire when Mario is next to or on them.

image.name: Bill Blaster sprite.

item.name: 1 up Mushroom
item.description: Green mushrooms that give Mario an extra life when collected. 1 up mushrooms are within invisible blocks near pits. When one is struck, the mushroom travels across the ground in the opposite direction from Mario.

image.name: SMB 1-up Mushroom Sprite.png

item.name: Coin
item.description: Coins float in mid-air throughout levels and within blocks. Collecting one awards Mario 200 points. Collecting 100 awards him an extra life.

image.name: Sprite of a coin from Super Mario Bros.

item.name: Koopa shell
item.description: Stomping on a Koopa Troopa makes it recede into its shell. Its sent sliding when touched, defeating enemies on contact. Doing so causes the "bulldozer attack", where each enemy defeated grants Mario more points than the last. Launched shells ricochet off collided walls and can damage Mario on contact.

image.name: Green Shell

item.name: Buzzy shell
item.description: Stomping on a Buzzy Beetle yields a shell that works like the Koopa ones, but it cannot be cleared away with tossed fireballs.

image.name: A Buzzy Shell

power_up.description: Mario is in this small-sized form when the player starts a new game. Regular Mario is incapable of breaking bricks and loses a life when he makes contact with an enemy or obstacle. However, he can run across narrow passageways without having to crouch. Regardless of the form he was in before losing a life, Mario reappears in the level in his regular form.

image.name: Small Mario sprite from Super Mario Bros.
Luigi's death sprite in Super Mario Bros.

power_up.name: Magic Mushroom
power_up.description: The red Magic Mushrooms are within visible blocks and slide across the ground, similar to 1 up mushrooms. They bounce back in the opposite direction when they hit an obstruction. Touching one transforms Mario into Super Mario, a form twice as tall as his regular form and capable of breaking bricks. Subsequent encounters with blocks intended to contain Magic Mushrooms instead release Fire Flowers when struck in this form. Receiving damaging in this form reverts Mario back into his regular-sized state. He retains this form across levels if he reaches flagpoles as Super Mario.

image.name: SMB Supermushroom.png
Super Mario jumping in Super Mario Bros.
Sprite of Luigi from Super Mario Bros.

power_up.name: Fire Flower
power_up.description: Making contact with a Fire Flower transforms Mario into Fiery Mario. In this form, Mario can toss projectile fireballs with  that bounce along the ground. Most enemies are defeated when hit. Fiery Mario also has all the benefits of Super Mario, and similarly retains this form if he completes the level in it. Mario reverts to his regular size if hit as Fiery Mario.

image.name: Sprite of a Fire Flower from Super Mario Bros.
SMB Fire Mario Sprite.png
SMB Fire Mario Sprite.png

power_up.name: Starman
power_up.description: Starmen are rare power-ups often hidden in invisible blocks. When released, they bounce in the opposite direction from Mario. When grabbed, Mario is transformed into Invincible Mario for thirty seconds. In this state, Mario is largely indestructible and defeats enemies on contact. Contact with the Starman does not wholly replace the form Mario was already in (i.e., Mario remains small if one is touched while in his regular form, and he can still toss fireballs if he is in his Fiery form.) Invincible Mario cannot be carried over to subsequent levels.

image.name: Sprite of a Starman from Super Mario Bros.
Invincible Mario in Super Mario Bros.
Invincible Mario in Super Mario Bros.

object.name: ? block
object.description: Floating blocks that contain items. One releases its contents when jumped underneath. Some ? blocks are ten-coin blocks that release up to 10 coins if struck in rapid succession. Others are invisible. A struck ? block becomes an empty block that can be used as platforms. These are the only type of strikable blocks that regular Mario can open.

image.name: An static ? Block from Super Mario Bros. (Overworld palette)

object.name: Brick
object.description: The most common blocks. Most bricks fall apart when struck, but some are secretly ? or ten-coin blocks. Regular Mario is incapable of directly breaking a brick block, but he can still use a shell if available.

image.name: Sprite of a Brick Block from Super Mario Bros.

object.name: Coral
object.description: Coral form varyingly sized columns in underwater levels that obstruct Mario.

image.name: Sprite of Coral from Super Mario Bros.

object.name: Small cloud
object.description: Cloud-like blocks make up the terrain in Bonus Stages high in the sky.

image.name: Sprite of a Cloud Block from Super Mario Bros.

object.name: Stairblock
object.description: Unbreakable blocks that appear on the ground. Some are stacked or laid next to each other to form climbable staircases or incomplete bridges.

image.name: Sprite of a Hard Block from Super Mario Bros.

object.name: Jumping board
object.description: Jumping boards bounce Mario into the air. Pressing  when the the spring is fully contracted makes a jumping board launch Mario much higher than it would otherwise.

image.name: Jumping board

object.name: Lift
object.description: Thin, moving platforms. They are most common in athletic levels, above bottomless pits. Lifts are of varying widths and movements. There is a paired type of Lifts called Balance Lifts that are a seesaw-like pulley system, where standing on one Lift makes it fall and the other rise. There are also types of Lifts that fall shortly after being stepped on.

image.name: SMBPlatform.png

object.name: Pipe
object.description: Most pipes are columnar platforms of varying height, some of which contain Piranha plants. A few of them are Warp Pipes that bring Mario to a secret underground area by pressing down on .

image.name: Sprite of a Warp Pipe from Super Mario Bros.

object.name: Super mushroom
object.description: Giant mushrooms that occur in athletic levels, high above bottomless pits.

image.name: A Mushroom Platform from Super Mario Bros.

object.name: Ax
object.description: Touching an ax causes the bridge it is alongside to collapse. This defeats the boss that was on top of it and completes the level.

image.name: Sprite of an Axe from Super Mario Bros.

object.name: Flagpole
object.description: Flagpoles are the goals at the end of most levels. When one is touched, Mario slides to the base and completes the level. Touching one also rewards him bonus points. The higher he is on the flagpole, the greater the number of points. Grabbing the top rewards Mario 5000 points.

image.name: A flagpole from Super Mario Bros.

object.name: Beanstalk
object.description: Beanstalks rapidly grow from struck vine blocks, ascending skyward. Climbing one brings Mario to a hidden Bonus Stage in the sky.

image.name: Beanstalk

object.name: Firework
object.description: Fireworks appear if Mario grabs a flagpole with 1, 3, or 6 as the last digit on the timer. The number of fireworks that go off correlates with this number, and each one rewards Mario 500 points.

image.name: Sprite of a Firework from Super Mario Bros.

object.name: Horsehair plant
object.description: Field horsehair plants appear in the background of ground-themed levels. According to the instruction booklet, Bowser transformed some of the Mushroom Kingdom's inhabitants into these plants.

image.name: A horsehair plant from Super Mario Bros.

reference.name: Donkey Kong
reference.description: The design for lifts resembles the girders seen in 100m.

reference.name: Donkey Kong Jr.
reference.description: Trampolines return with a similar design.

reference.name: Mario Bros.
reference.description: Green pipes, coins and blocks, introduced to the Mario universe in this game, return. Koopa Troopas are derived from this game's Shellcreepers.

reference.name: Donkey Kong
reference.description: For the NES release of this game, Mario's jumping sprite from Super Mario Bros. is used on the box art.

reference.name: Mario Bros.
reference.description: For the NES release of this game, Mario's jumping sprite from Super  is used on the box art.

reference.name: Super Mario Bros. 2
reference.description: The non-Japanese sequel to Super Mario Bros. Mushrooms, Stars, and Shells appear.

reference.name: Super Mario Bros. 3
reference.description: Bowser returns along with the rest of the Koopa Troop, as well as elements from the original Super Mario Bros. When Princess Toadstool is saved, she says, "Thank you! But our Princess is in another castle!…Just kidding!" That is a reference to Toad's lines in Super Mario Bros.  The original Super Mario Bros. Ground Theme plays when the Music Box is used.

reference.name: Super Mario Land
reference.description: Mario's sprites in this game is near identical to his sprites from Super Mario Bros. Gameplay is also near-identical.

reference.name: Alleyway
reference.description: Several sprites from Super Mario Bros. appear in bonus levels.

reference.name: Super Mario World 2: Yoshi's Island
reference.description: The course clear fanfare can be heard after Baby Mario and Baby Luigi return to their home.

reference.name: Super Mario RPG: Legend of the Seven Stars
reference.description: If the player goes behind a curtain in Booster Tower, Mario briefly turns into his 8-bit sprite from Super Mario Bros.

reference.name: Super Mario 64
reference.description: Outside the Warp Pipe that leads to the final boss, carved into pillars are what look like sprites of Mario and Bowser from Super Mario Bros.

reference.name: Paper Mario
reference.description: The Thousand-Year Door, his allies will not become an 8-bit form. Goombario also references Super Mario Bros. in the Goomba's Tattle entry.

reference.name: Super Smash Bros.
reference.description: When Mario performs his taunt, he mimics his standing pose in Super Mario Bros. Also, Mario's and Luigi's victory fanfare is a version of the course clear theme. Mario and Luigi's helpless animations are based on the pose Mario and Luigi take upon defeat in Super Mario Bros. Many items from Super Mario Bros. are usable in this game. One of Luigi's alternate colors bears resemblance to his colors in Super Mario Bros.

reference.name: Game & Watch Gallery 3
reference.description: Playing Star Mode for the Modern version of Donkey Kong Jr. will have the Goomba enemies being replaced by Spinies, similar to the new quest mode in Super Mario Bros. replacing the Goombas with Buzzy Beetles.

reference.name: Luigi's Mansion
reference.description: Although not distinctly noted as such, the idea of King Boo using a Bowser decoy (through the magic of his) may be loosely based on the seven fake Bowsers in Super Mario Bros.

reference.name: Super Smash Bros. Melee
reference.description: Many enemies from Super Mario Bros. appear in this game's Adventure Mode.

reference.name: Super Mario Sunshine
reference.description: A castle level is seen when Mario first met F.L.U.D.D. Various 8-bit patterns are seen in the background of the secret levels of Ricco Harbor and Sirena Beach.

reference.name: Super Mario Advance 4: Super Mario Bros. 3
reference.description: Some of the available levels for World-e include reproductions of Super Mario Bros.'s Worlds 1-1, 1-2, 1-3, 1-4, and 2-2 in Super Mario Bros. 3's style. Only World 1-1 was originally made available outside Japan.

reference.name: Game & Watch Gallery 4
reference.description: Like in Game & Watch Gallery 3 above, playing Star Mode for the Modern version of Donkey Kong Jr. will have the Goomba enemies being replaced by Spinies, similar to the new quest mode in Super Mario Bros. replacing the Goombas with Buzzy Beetles.

reference.name: Mario & Luigi: Superstar Saga
reference.description: At the Border between the Mushroom Kingdom and the Beanbean Kingdom, there's a minigame called Border Jump that uses the level end of most levels in Super Mario Bros. (including the flagpole, fortress, and fireworks for success). Also, there is a 2D obstacle room before Roy's room which ends with Mario getting the ax and burning the Bowser decoy above a lava bridge. A type of Question Block from Super Mario Bros. can be seen among other types.

reference.name: Paper Mario: The Thousand-Year Door
reference.description: If the player jumps up into a vent and then comes down into the changing room in the X-Naut Fortress then Mario and all his allies will become 8-bit and similar in style to the Super Mario Bros. sprites.

reference.name: Mario Superstar Baseball
reference.description: The loading screen has Mario hitting a ? Block in graphics from Super Mario Bros.

reference.name: Mario & Luigi: Partners in Time
reference.description: Toadsworth the Younger states when Baby Peach flies away "You will save her, won't you? I assure you she's NOT in another castle.", referencing the mushroom retainers' famous line "Thank you, Mario! But our princess is in another castle!".

reference.name: Tetris DS
reference.description: The first two levels were World 1-1, 3 and 7 were underground based, 8 and 9 are up in heights, and 10 was a castle.

reference.name: New Super Mario Bros.
reference.description: Many things from Super Mario Bros. return here, such as flagpoles, Warp Zones (in the form of cannons), and the title screen's logo typeface. When connecting to a multiplayer game, Mario can be seen running what looks like World 1-2. Also, a close-up of Mario from Super Mario Bros. as well as a picture from said game are unlockable backgrounds. The sound effect that plays when Mario or Luigi slides down the Goal Pole is reused, albeit in reversed form. One of the multiplayer stages is a truncated looping version of World 1-1. The second level is a cave level with a secret path over the ceiling leading to a secret exit, similar to the secret path over this game's World 1-2. The main boss of World 1 is Bowser, who is defeated by breaking his bridge and dropping him into lava, and the first main boss of World 8 features Dry Bowser, who is defeated in the same way, and throws bones like how Bowser threw hammers in later levels of this game.

reference.name: Mario Hoops 3-on-3
reference.description: In Mario Stadium, one can see an 8-bit Mario chasing two Goombas. Also, the music for Bowser's Castle is a cover of the Castle Theme.

reference.name: Super Paper Mario
reference.description: The sprites of Mario, Luigi, Peach, and Bowser appear around said character when they collect the Pal Pills. Also, when any character (including a Koopa Troopa) grabs a Mega Star, they turn into a huge version of their Super Mario Bros. sprites. (Mario and Luigi are their Small forms in both). Portions of Chapter 1-1, Chapter 3-1, and Chapter 5-3 are also identical to Worlds 1-1, 1-2, and 2-1, respectively.

reference.name: Super Mario Galaxy
reference.description: In Toy Time Galaxy, there's a huge 8-bit Mario/Luigi. Also in Flipswitch Galaxy, the background contains an overworld scene and an underground scene from this game.

reference.name: Super Smash Bros. Brawl
reference.description: The stage Mushroomy Kingdom is based on Worlds 1-1 and 1-2 of this game. Lakitu and Spinies and Hammer Bro appear as Assist Trophies. Lakitu and Spinies retain their original 8-bit look from Super Mario Bros. Also, many enemies from Super Mario Bros. appear in this game's Subspace Emissary Mode.

reference.name: WarioWare: D.I.Y.
reference.description: The Crayon Epic microgame features a monster spitting fireballs identical to Lava Bubble's sprite from this game.

reference.name: New Super Mario Bros. Wii
reference.description: The second level of Coin Courses looks exactly like World 1-1 from Super Mario Bros.

reference.name: Super Mario Galaxy 2
reference.description: In Twisty Trials Galaxy  and the second area of the Grandmaster Galaxy, there is a backdrop showing moving sprites of items and an 8-bit Mario and Luigi from this game. Mario Squared Galaxy takes place on an 8-bit Mario, as well as an 8-bit Luigi (during the mission "Luigi's Purple Coin Chaos"), Mario and Luigi's sprites from this game.

reference.name: Super Mario 3D Land
reference.description: Mario's sprite from Super Mario Bros. is used as the marker of where Mario is in a world. Tail Bowsers are similar to Fake Bowsers, and the first one is a disguised Goomba. The second level has a ledge just out of view that allows the player to walk over the level, and ends in a secret Pipe.

reference.name: Mario Kart 7
reference.description: Piranha Plant Slide is heavily based on the underground levels of Super Mario Bros. The cloud and bushes in the race course are the same model in different colors, referencing how the clouds and bushes in Super Mario Bros. are the same sprite in different colors.

reference.name: New Super Mario Bros. 2
reference.description: The first course in Coin Rush's Gold Classics Pack is based on Worlds 1-1 and 1-2. Also, the last course is based on World 1-4.

reference.name: New Super Mario Bros. U
reference.description: Sprites from Super Mario Bros. are used in the game menus. The second level is an underground course with a secret path over the ceiling leading to a secret exit. The first phase of the final boss involves striking an ax to Bowser's bridge to drop him into lava.

reference.name: New Super Luigi U
reference.description: Various sprites of Luigi are reused as hidden Luigis.

reference.name: Super Mario 3D World
reference.description: Mario's sprite from Super Mario Bros. is seen on the saving screen. His sprite can also be seen in a bonus area of Bob-ombs Below. Luigi's sprite can be spotted in some levels and on the button to enter the Luigi Bros. game.

reference.name: NES Remix
reference.description: Super Mario Bros. is a game remixed in this game.

reference.name: Mario Party: Island Tour
reference.description: The theme heard in the minigames Xylophone Home and Goomba Tower Takedown is a remix of the Ground Theme.

reference.name: NES Remix 2
reference.description: A port of the game titled Super Luigi Bros. appears, where the player controls Luigi, and all the levels are mirrored.

reference.name: Mario Kart 8
reference.description: Various sprites of enemies and scenery can be seen on pots in Bone-Dry Dunes. Super Bell Subway has graffiti representing World 1-2. Also, Piranha Plant Slide, which is based heavily on the underground levels of Super Mario Bros., returns from Mario Kart 7.

reference.name: Super Smash Bros. for Nintendo 3DS / Wii U
reference.description: Fire Bars appear as an item in these games. In Super Smash Bros. for Nintendo 3DS, the Mushroomy Kingdom stage from Super Mario Bros., returns from Super Smash Bros. Brawl, though without World 1-2.

reference.name: Ultimate NES Remix
reference.description: A port of the game titled Speed Mario Bros. appears in which the game runs twice as fast.

reference.name: Yoshi's Woolly World
reference.description: The Shell Patch enemy greatly resembles a Red Shell's sprite in this game.

reference.name: Super Mario Maker
reference.description: The game is used as one of the graphical styles for these games.

reference.name: Mario & Sonic at the Rio 2016 Olympic Games (Nintendo 3DS)
reference.description: A structure in the shape of a Castle from Super Mario Bros. made of Brick Blocks and character wall obstacles of Mario, Bowser, Lakitu, Spinies and Goombas using their sprites from Super Mario Bros. appear as obstacles in Golf Plus.

reference.name: Super Mario Odyssey
reference.description: In some parts of the game, Mario can walk within walls from a 2D perspective that uses sprites and sound effects from Super Mario Bros., as well as altering the music to an 8-bit variation. A scene of Mario confronting Bowser in Super Mario Bros. can be seen when Mario captures Bowser in this game. A replica of World 1-1 can be played in a theater in New Donk City.

reference.name: Super Mario Party
reference.description: Mario's, Goomba's, Spiny's, Cheep Cheep's, and Bowser's sprites appear in Puzzle Hustle. Dart Gallery's background features neon lights resembling Super Mario Bros.'s overworld levels.

reference.name: Super Smash Bros. Ultimate
reference.description: The Mushroom Kingdom stage from Super Smash Bros. returns in this game, along with Mushroomy Kingdom.

reference.name: Mario Kart Tour
reference.description: The 8-Bit Jumping Mario, 8-Bit Jumping Luigi, 8-Bit Star, 8-Bit Bullet Bill, 8-Bit Fire Flower, 8-Bit Super Mushroom, 8-Bit Block Glider, and 8-Bit Goomba are re-creations of their sprites in Super Mario Bros. The Super 1 uses the Japanese logo of Super Mario Bros.

reference.name: Mario & Sonic at the Olympic Games Tokyo 2020
reference.description: The sprites for Mario, Luigi, Princess Toadstool, Bowser, Little Goombas, Koopa Troopas, Hammer Bros, Lakitus, and Mushroom Retainers are reused in the 2D Events. In these events differently colored Toads appear which have sprites that are based on the sprite for red Mushroom Retainers in Super Mario Bros.

reference.name: Mario + Rabbids Sparks of Hope
reference.description: Whenever Rabbid Mario retrieves a Purified Darkmess Energy Crystal, he plays the Course Clear theme on his mandolin.

reference.name: Super Mario Bros. Wonder
reference.description: Launch to Victory, during the Wonder Flower's effect, there is a block formation referencing the Fire Flower sprite.

version.description: Original Nintendo Entertainment System release (North America/Japan)
Re-released on the Family Computer Disk System in Japan as one of the launch titles.
Released for the arcade VS. System as VS. Super Mario Bros.
A Game & Watch titled Super Mario Bros. is released, but it is a completely different game.
Ported into the arcade machine Nintendo PlayChoice-10.
Released on the Family Computer Disk System as All Night Nippon: Super Mario Bros. Most of the levels have been reused but the physics engine is from Super Mario Bros.: The Lost Levels.
Original Nintendo Entertainment System release (Europe/Australia)
Re-released on the NES in North America as part of the 2-in-1 Super Mario Bros./Duck Hunt compilation, packaged with the NES Action Set.
A Nelsonic Game Watch titled Super Mario Bros. is released, but it is a completely different game.
Re-released on the NES in North America as part of the 3-in-1 Super Mario Bros./Duck Hunt/World Class Track Meet compilation, packaged with the NES Power Set.
Re-released on the NES as part of Nintendo World Championships 1990.
Re-released on the NES in Europe as part of the 3-in-1 Super Mario Bros./Tetris/Nintendo World Cup compilation, sold alone or with the Top Loader.
Remake available on the Super Nintendo Entertainment System as part of the Super Mario All-Stars compilation. Graphics and sound were updated, and many glitches were removed.
Remake available on the SNES in North America as part of the Super Mario All-Stars + Super Mario World compilation, packaged with the SNES Mario Set.
A special version is released as a Satellaview broadcast titled BS Super Mario Collection - Dai-1-Shuu, which is based on the Super Mario All-Stars version.
Remake released on the Game Boy Color as Super Mario Bros. Deluxe. The game featured the original game's graphics but loads of additional content.

The original game is available as an unlockable NES game in Doubutsu no Mori+. In Japan, it is obtainable only through the thirty Nintendo GameCube Memory Cards that were distributed as part of a sweepstakes in Famitsu magazine.[25] In the international release, it can only be unlocked by using a cheating device. It was likely going to be released as an e-Reader card (as were Ice Climber and Mario Bros.), but a Super Mario Bros. card was never released. In the Japan-only re-release, Doubutsu no Mori e+, the game is removed altogether.

In celebrating 20 years of the Famicom in Japan, Nintendo ran a "Hot Mario Campaign" from November 7, 2003 to January 15, 2004, in which the prize was a special edition of Super Mario Bros. alongside a Famicom-themed Game Boy Advance.[26][27]

The original game was re-released on the Game Boy Advance as part of the NES Classics / Famicom Mini collection, celebrating 20 years of the Famicom in Japan. It was also re-released on September 13, 2005, in Japan to celebrate 20 years of the original NES game.
Available on the Wii as part of the Virtual Console. It requires 23 blocks (2.9 MB) to be installed.
Available as a playable demo in Super Smash Bros. Brawl.
SNES version re-released with Super Mario All-Stars Limited Edition.
Virtual Console port titled 25th Anniversary SUPER MARIO BROS. with the question marks on the ? Blocks replaced with "25", exclusively bundled with a special, red Wii.

Released on the 3DS as part of the Virtual Console. It is a free download for those who purchased a 3DS before the August 12th price drop. The full release version was released on January 5, 2012, in Japan, on February 16, 2012, in North America, and on March 1, 2012, in Europe and Australia.

Released on the Wii U as part of the Virtual Console service via the Wii U eShop in Japan on June 5 and in Europe, Australia, and North America in September.  It requires 15 MB to be installed. The game was also featured in NES Remix.
Re-released in NES Remix 2 as Super Luigi Bros. The game was also featured in Ultimate NES Remix along with the port of Super Mario Bros., Speed Mario Bros.
Available as a playable demo in Super Smash Bros. for Wii U.
Available as a "highlight" in amiibo tap: Nintendo's Greatest Bits.
Released as one of the 30 games included in the NES Classic Edition and Nintendo Classic Mini: Family Computer.
Available as one of the 20 NES titles at the Nintendo Switch Online subscription service's launch in September 2018, and for the first time can be played with other players online.[28]
Released as Super Mario Bros. 35.
Released as Game & Watch: Super Mario Bros.

image.name: SMB Super Mushroom Screenshot.png

item.name: Coin
item.description: 10 in ?s, up to 10 in one Ten-Coin Block, and 19 in open air in the secret area.

item.name: Starman
item.description: Hidden in a brick.

item.name: 1 up Mushroom
item.description: Hidden in an invisible block in between the fourth pipe and the first Pit.

image.name: SMB Super Mushroom Screenshot.png

item.name: Coin
item.description: 4 in ? blocks, up to 30 across three Coin Blocks, and 34 in open air, 17 of which are in the secret area. An additional 22 coins are located in the secret area exclusive to Super Mario Bros Deluxe's challenge mode, 9 of which are in open air, three are located in ? blocks, and up to 10 can be found in one Coin Block.

item.name: Starman
item.description: Hidden in a Brick Block.

item.name: 1 up Mushroom
item.description: Hidden in a Brick Block that is a part of the ceiling, above the rightmost edge of the rectangle of Brick Blocks with six coins above it.

image.name: SMB Super Mushroom Screenshot.png

item.name: Coin
item.description: All coins are found in the open. Additionally, collecting 21 of them in the level will cause a 1-Up Mushroom to appear within a hidden block in World 2-1.

item.name: Coin
item.description: All coins are found in hidden blocks right before Fake Bowser.

item.name: Coin
item.description: 17 in ?s, up to 10 in one Ten-Coin Block, 2 in invisible blocks, 41 in open air in the Coin Heaven, and 19 in open air in the bonus room.

item.name: Starman
item.description: Hidden in a brick.

item.name: 1 up Mushroom
item.description: Hidden in an invisible block above the area with two Green Koopa Troopas after the first staircase. Hitting another invisible block is required to reach it. Appears after collecting 21 coins in World 1-3 or continuing after a Game Over.
